statement.text: Femoral artery exposure is the most fundamental vascular surgery technique, providing access to the common femoral artery (CFA), superficial femoral artery (SFA), and profunda femoris artery (PFA). This exposure serves as the foundation for bypass grafting, endarterectomy, embolectomy, and endovascular access. Mastery of femoral exposure anatomy is essential for all vascular surgeons.
statement.formal: Femoral Exposure: Vertical/oblique groin incision → CFA/SFA/PFA exposure → Circumferential dissection with vessel loops | Landmarks: Inguinal ligament, femoral pulse, sartorius | Critical: Femoral vein medial, profunda posterolateral | Applications: Bypass, endarterectomy, embolectomy, endovascular

explanation.intuition: Think of femoral exposure as accessing the main highway junction of the leg's blood supply. The common femoral artery is like a major interstate that splits into two roads - the superficial femoral going down the front of the thigh to the knee, and the profunda going deep into the thigh muscles. Surgeons need to access this junction safely while avoiding the vein that runs right next to it.
explanation.key_insight: The femoral artery is the most commonly accessed artery in vascular surgery because it's relatively superficial, large enough to work with, and sits at a key anatomic junction. However, complications can be devastating - injury to the femoral vein can cause severe bleeding, lymphatic disruption leads to troublesome wound problems, and the femoral nerve controls thigh sensation and strength.
explanation.technical_details: Technique: (1) Patient supine with leg externally rotated; (2) Incision: vertical or oblique 2 fingerbreadths below inguinal ligament, centered on femoral pulse; (3) Divide subcutaneous tissue and Scarpa's fascia; (4) Identify and preserve lymphatics when possible; (5) Incise femoral sheath longitudinally; (6) Dissect CFA circumferentially; (7) Trace distally to identify SFA/PFA bifurcation; (8) PFA takeoff is posterolateral, typically 3-5cm below inguinal ligament; (9) Lateral circumflex iliac vein crosses field - ligate if needed; (10) Place vessel loops on CFA, SFA, PFA for control. The SFA is more anterior and superficial; PFA dives deep and posteriorly. The profunda branches (lateral circumflex, medial circumflex) may require additional dissection.
common_misconceptions: The SFA is the main blood supply to the leg - the PFA is often more important, especially in occlusive disease
Femoral exposure is easy because the artery is superficial - proper tissue handling to avoid lymphatic complications requires skill
A bigger incision is always better - excessive dissection increases lymphatic complications
The femoral vein is always medial - anatomic variations occur, especially with scarred groins

definitions_glossary.common_femoral_artery: The external iliac artery after it passes under the inguinal ligament
definitions_glossary.superficial_femoral_artery: The continuation of the CFA after the profunda takeoff, runs in the adductor canal
definitions_glossary.profunda_femoris: Deep femoral artery, major blood supply to the thigh muscles
definitions_glossary.femoral_sheath: Fascial compartment containing femoral artery, vein, and canal
definitions_glossary.inguinal_ligament: Ligament from ASIS to pubic tubercle, key landmark for femoral exposure

indications: Endovascular access for aortic and iliac interventions
contraindications: Active groin infection (relative - may need alternative exposure)
Hostile groin (prior radiation, multiple surgeries - consider alternative access)
Femoral artery occlusion (for endovascular access - use alternative site)

technique.positioning: Supine with mild external rotation and abduction of the leg

incision_options.vertical: Easier extension, standard for most cases
incision_options.oblique: May heal better in obese patients, follows skin lines

key_structures.femoral_vein: Lies medial to artery, be careful with retraction
key_structures.femoral_nerve: Lateral to artery, outside femoral sheath
key_structures.lateral_circumflex_vein: Crosses anterior to artery at bifurcation, may need ligation
key_structures.lymphatics: Multiple superficial nodes, preserve when possible

steps: Identify femoral pulse (or use ultrasound if absent)
Make incision 2 fingerbreadths below inguinal ligament
Divide skin, subcutaneous tissue, Scarpa's fascia
Identify femoral sheath and incise longitudinally
Place vessel loops on all three vessels
Extend dissection as needed for planned procedure

complications.management: Antibiotics, drainage, sartorius flap coverage if deep

complications.prevention: Careful medial dissection, identify vein early
Stay medial to sartorius, avoid lateral retraction
complications.management: Usually traction injury, recovers over months

definition.@value: Surgical exposure of the common, superficial, and profunda femoral arteries through a groin incision for vascular procedures

sources.citation: Rutherford's Vascular Surgery, 9th Edition. Chapter on Lower Extremity Arterial Exposure.
Standard vascular surgery training curriculum, ACGME requirements.

learning_objectives: Describe the anatomy of the femoral triangle and femoral vessels
Perform surgical exposure of the common, superficial, and profunda femoral arteries
Identify and protect adjacent structures (vein, nerve, lymphatics)
Recognize and manage complications of femoral exposure
clinical_pearls: The profunda femoris is the key vessel - always ensure it's preserved in occlusive disease
External rotation of the leg brings the femoral artery more anterior and superficial
If you can't feel a pulse, use ultrasound to mark the artery before incision
The lateral circumflex vein crosses the field at the bifurcation - anticipate and ligate
Lymphatic complications are the most common - handle tissues gently
